title: Christian Conduct and Judgment
shortSummary: 1 Corinthians 6 addresses the responsibility of believers to resolve disputes within the church rather than before secular courts, emphasizing the saints' future role in judgment. The chapter also confronts immoral behavior, urging believers to honor God with their bodies as temples of the Holy Spirit.
timeline: c. AD 55 - Paul's First Letter to the Corinthians during his Third Missionary Journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The Apostle who authored this letter, instructing the Corinthian church on matters of judgment, morality, and Christian living.

keyCharacters.name: The Corinthians
keyCharacters.description: Members of the church in Corinth who are being corrected for their disputes and immoral behavior.

definitions.definition: Believers in Christ who are set apart for God and called to live holy lives.
Avoiding sexual immorality, which is any sexual activity outside the bounds of biblical marriage.
The believer’s body, indwelt by the Holy Spirit, making it sacred and to be honored.
Declared righteous before God through faith in Jesus Christ.

outline.heading: Believers Should Judge Disputes Among Themselves
outline.description: Paul rebukes the Corinthians for taking their disputes before secular courts instead of resolving them within the church, reminding them that the saints will judge the world and even angels.

outline.heading: Warning Against Lawsuits Among Believers
outline.description: Paul expresses shame that believers are suing each other and encourages them to endure wrong rather than harm the testimony of the church by public lawsuits.

outline.heading: The Unrighteous Will Not Inherit God’s Kingdom
outline.description: A list of sinful behaviors is given, with a strong warning that those who practice such things will not inherit the kingdom of God, but believers have been washed, sanctified, and justified.

outline.heading: Christian Liberty and Responsibility
outline.description: Paul acknowledges Christian freedom but stresses that not all things are beneficial and that the body is meant for the Lord, not for sin.

outline.heading: The Believer’s Body as a Member of Christ
outline.description: Paul teaches that believers’ bodies are members of Christ and temples of the Holy Spirit, exhorting them to flee sexual immorality and glorify God with their bodies.

application: Seek to resolve conflicts within the church community rather than taking disputes to secular courts.
Recognize the importance of holiness by fleeing sexual immorality and honoring God with your body.
Remember that your body is the temple of the Holy Spirit and live in a way that glorifies God in both body and spirit.
Exercise Christian liberty responsibly, avoiding anything that might bring you under the power of sin.

keyVerses.text: What? know ye not that your body is the temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you, which ye have of God, and ye are not your own?
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the sacredness of the believer’s body as indwelt by the Holy Spirit, calling for purity and honor.

keyVerses.text: And such were some of you: but ye are washed, but ye are sanctified, but ye are justified in the name of the Lord Jesus, and by the Spirit of our God.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the transformative power of the gospel in the lives of believers, calling them to live in holiness.

keyVerses.text: Flee fornication. Every sin that a man doeth is without the body; but he that committeth fornication sinneth against his own body.
keyVerses.significance: This verse commands believers to actively avoid sexual immorality, emphasizing its unique harm to the body.
